title: Warm winter proves a record setter, especially in Ohio
summary:
Average temperatures in Ohio reached 34.8 degrees from December through February – 6 degrees above normal and good for the fifth warmest winter on record.
Michigan’s average of 26.3 was up 6.1 degrees from the historic norm and the state’s eighth warmest winter.
That made it the fourth warmest winter in Rhode Island’s history, and sixth warmest in Connecticut, Delaware, and New Jersey.
NOAA concluded that this winter’s unusually warm temperatures bore the signature of climate change.
But regardless of the role of the Arctic Oscillation, NOAA concluded that this year’s warm winter presents a cause for greater concern.

title: Cincinnati Zoo gorilla Samantha dies at 50
summary:
(Photo: Liz Dufour/The Enquirer)Samantha, the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden’s oldest mammal and matriarch of its gorillas, has died.
Zoo officials said Samantha was euthanized Sunday morning due to "age-related health issues."
Nicknamed "The Grand Old Lady of the Cincinnati Zoo," Samantha gave birth to six offspring.
Samantha, right, and her adopted daughter, Elle, 4, venture into their indoor habitat at the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden Friday, January.
(Photo: Provided/ Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden)Samantha and another gorilla, Sam, were born about a week apart in 1970 and were the first two gorilla babies born and raised at the Cincinnati Zoo, according to zoo officials.

title: ShotSpotter expanding to six more Cincinnati neighborhoods in 2020
summary:
CINCINNATI — ShotSpotter recorded 168 reports of shots fired in the Price Hill and Avondale areas during New Year’s celebrations this week.
ShotSpotter, which uses a network of microphones to pinpoint shootings, will expand into the West End, Over-the-Rhine, Westwood, Millvale, South Fairmount and Evanston by year's end.
And some people in other Cincinnati neighborhoods, like Jamison Walker, say the technology can't come their way soon enough.
"You hear bangs, and whether it's a gunshot or fireworks, you don't know," said Mark Brungart of Over-the-Rhine, one of the neighborhoods getting ShotSpotter this year.
Cincinnati police hope to have the expanded ShotSpotter technology in place by this summer to get ahead of the typical uptick at that time of year.

The 4G phone showed 160 megabytes per second, while the the new 5G phone was 8 times faster at just over 1,200 megabytes.
Verizon says it is currently the only carrier with true wide band 5G in Cincinnati.

title: Spring in January? Record Breaking Warmth Saturday
summary:
Spring-like trend Friday and Saturday across the Ohio valley with temperatures well above average highs.
A major storm system pulls warm, tropical air as far north as the Ohio valley with strong southerly wind.
And with that stronger southerly flow temperatures jump into the 60s and low 70s for some in Ohio.
Warm enough to break 130 year old records for some major cities in the Buckeye state!
Cities like Dayton, Columbus and Cincinnati most likely will have new record high temperatures.

title: Cincinnati School Closes for Day Due to Widespread Illness
summary:
CINCINNATI, Ohio -The flu season is one of the worst doctors have seen in a decade, and now it is closing schools in Ohio.
The elementary school at Summit Academy Cincinnati gave a sick day to the entire student body Friday, January 10, due to widespread illness among students and staff.
Children are among the groups most at risk for developing the flu and its complications and are more likely to spread the illness to others.
Doctors say it is not too late to get a flu shot.
More information about the flu and where to find a flu shot is available at www.flu.ohio.gov.

“Many of our banking center, operations and call center employees are coming to work while facing challenges related to childcare, transportation or general concern for their family’s well-being,” said Greg D. Carmichael, chairman, president and CEO of Fifth Third Bancorp.

He led the Archdiocese of Cincinnati for 27 years, taking over when Cardinal Joseph Bernardin left Cincinnati for Chicago.
He resigned from his position as Archbishop of Cincinnati in 2009, after 50 years of priesthood.

“Our Event Center, gift shop, and Aquifer bar are all closed, of course, but they represent a fairly small percentage of our business.
“We’re at nearly full operation, and, thankfully, shipping everything we’ve put into a bottle—I say nearly full operation because we’re following all CDC protocols and have a handful of production workers self-isolating,” Lewis said.
“I think we’re living proof of the adage that in good times and bad, the alcohol business is the place to be.

(April 12, 1947 – April 13, 2020)James Gilbert, age 73, passed away on Monday, April 13, 2020, in Comanche County, Texas.
He was born on April 12, 1947, in Cincinnati, Ohio, to Charles and Margaret Eloise (Meyer) Gilbert.
On July 2, 1965, he was united in marriage to Revon Marie Walls in Hamilton County, Ohio.
He is survived by his wife of fifty-four years, Revon Gilbert of Comanche County; daughter, Carrie Greene and husband Ben of Blum; sons, James Gilbert, Jr. and wife Jeanie of Ohio and Richard Gilbert of Ohio; eight grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren.
He was preceded in death by his parents, Charles and Margaret Gilbert.

title: Full Hunter's Moon will appear for three days this weekend in Cincinnati, Ohio
summary:
(Photo: Kareem Elgazzar)October's full moon is called the Hunter's Moon and can be seen this weekend, according to the Old Farmer's Almanac.
The Hunter's Moon will be visible from Saturday morning to Tuesday morning.
The Hunter's Moon is not particularly different from any other full moon.
It relates to the Harvest Moon, which occurred in September and marks the autumnal equinox.
According to NASA, the first full moon after the Harvest Moon is called the Hunter's Moon, or any of these other nicknames: Travel Moon, Dying Grass Moon, Sanguine Moon and Blood Moon.

Blink will span from Findlay Market to Covington, bridging two states, and spanning 30 city blocks and the Ohio River.

title: Historic brewery in OTR goes up in flames Sunday morning
summary:
CINCINNATI — Flames tore through the historic Jackson Brewery in OTR Sunday morning, sending smoke into the air, which could be seen and smelled miles away.
Firefighters with the Cincinnati Fire Department responded to the former brewery at 208 Mohawk St. around 4:20 a.m. Sunday.
Part of the warehouse collapsed around 5:30 a.m., and later in the morning, the roof and other parts of the building collapsed.
Historic Limited Liability Company, LLC, is listed as the current owners of the brewery with the county auditor.
The building was built in 1850, and after its construction it housed Jackson Brewery before the brewery closed during Prohibition.

title: Adam Lee Roudebush December 3, 1979 – December 4, 2019
summary:
Adam Lee Roudebush, age 40 of Harrison, Ohio passed away Wednesday, December 4, 2019 at Good Samaritan Hospital in Cincinnati, Ohio.
Born December 3, 1979 in Cincinnati, Ohio the son of Mark and Robbin (Engle) Roudebush.
Adam graduated of William Henry Harrison High School in 1998.
Adam is survived by his Parents, Mark and Robbin Roudebush.
Brother of Christian (Kelly) Roudebush, uncle of Morgan and Brooke Roudebush and nephew of Sally Wind, Joy (Don) Brock and Karen (Walter) Schunk.

title: The Who Announce First Concert in Cincinnati Since Deadly 1979 Stampede
summary:
The Who, the band that defined British rock in the 1970s, said this week that it would return to the Cincinnati area in April for its first concert there since 11 fans were crushed to death in a stampede at one of the group’s shows in 1979.
The new concert was announced on Tuesday by the Cincinnati television station WCPO, which interviewed two band members, Pete Townshend and Roger Daltrey, for a documentary commemorating the tragedy’s 40th anniversary on Dec. 3 .
Tour,” the Who will perform on April 23 at BB&T Arena at Northern Kentucky University in Highland Heights, Ky., which is in the Cincinnati metropolitan area.
The band will donate some proceeds from the concert to the P.E.M.
Memorial Scholarship Fund, a Cincinnati group founded in 2010 in honor of three high school students who died at the 1979 concert.

title: What kind of winter are we in store for? It could be a 'polar coaster'
summary:
The 2020 Farmers’ Almanac’s extended weather forecast is calling for a “Polar Coaster Winter,” with frigid temperatures and snow for a majority of the country this winter.
That means us, Greater Cincinnati.
“We expect yet another wild ride this winter with extreme temperatures swings and some hefty snowfalls," said Editor Pete Geiger.
But we all know spring is the truly fickle season in Greater Cincinnati.

title: Storage facility fire in Colerain Township caused $1.5 million in damages
summary:
COLERAIN TOWNSHIP, Ohio — A Sunday morning fire in Colerain Township caused at least $1.5 million in damages, according to officials.
Large plumes of smoke were visible along I-74 near I-275 and in nearby communities.
Crews from Miami Township, Green Township, Whitewater Township and multiple other agencies, including the Greater Cincinnati Hazardous Materials Unit, responded to the fire.

title: Dalton returns and leads Bengals to 1st win, 22-6 over Jets
summary:
The Bengals (1-11) had lost 13 in a row since the end of last season, with newcomer Zac Taylor waiting until December to get his first head coaching win.
Taylor benched Dalton after the eighth loss, deciding to see whether Ryan Finley fit into the team’s long-term plans.
The Jets (4-8) had their three-game winning streak snapped, unable to extend their high-scoring momentum behind Sam Darnold.
An improving Bengals defense limited the Jets to their fewest points since a 33-0 loss to New England on Oct. 21.
New York lost to Miami, which was 0-7 at the time, on Nov. 3.
